Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for US participation in the conference "Latest in Geometric Analysis" that will be held November 24-30 of 2019 at the Mathematical Research and Conference Center in Bedlewo, Poland.

The conference focuses on recent developments in Analysis, especially in the fields of geometric analysis and geometric measure theory. A number of distinguished mathematicians have agreed to attend and speak at this conference. This award gives early career researchers, members of underrepresented groups, researchers not funded by NSF an opportunity to attend and participate in this conference. The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities. More information will be made available at: https://www.impan.pl/en/activities/banach-center/conferences/19-latest

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project enabled 13 US mathematicians to attend the conference "Latest in Geometric Analysis" at the Mathematical Research and Conference Center in Bedlewo, Poland. This international conference attracted speakers and researchers in geometric analysis from around the world and was part of the Simons Semester "Geometry and Analysis in Function and Mapping Theory on Euclidean and Metric Measure Spaces" organized by the Polish Academy of Sciences. It featured 21 plenary speakers, 5 contributed talks, posters by 21 young researchers, and 85 participants.

Attending the conference was important because the field is rapidly developing, so researchers need to keep up to date on the most recent developments and disseminate their own research. Main themes of the conference focused on non-smooth spaces and functions. These topics are important in both pure mathematics and in applications. For instance, non-smooth functions arise as solutions of partial differential equations in physics and non-smooth spaces can be used to understand the movement of objects under a control or constraint.

Effort was made to enable young US mathematicians to attend the conference. Of the thirteen mathematicians who were funded, three were graduate students, three were postdoctoral scholars, four were tenure track researchers not yet tenured, and four were tenured professors. Two funded participants gave a plenary talk, one give a contributed talk, and one funded participant gave a poster presentation. The attendees also attended numerous talks from leading researchers from around the world and collaborated on mathematical research with other attendees.
